University of South Africa Private Bag X6 Florida 1710 South Africa Graphical abstract The effect of activating atmosphere, reaction conditions and time on stream (TOS) on the catalytic performance and especially on the paraffin to olefin ratios (P/O) over an iron catalyst during Fischer-Tropsch synthesis was investigated. Activation with syngas led to better catalyst performance. For the long-term FT runs, although a higher catalytic activity and P/O ratio have been measured for the catalyst reduced by syngas, similar CO conversions, P/O ratios and product selectivity were achieved for the catalysts reduced by either syngas or H2 after 2200 h TOS, which indicates that no matter which kind of reducing agent is used to reduce the catalyst, the catalyst performance tends to be similar after a long TOS. Despite the P/O variations with different reaction conditions, a graphical approach (Yao plot) gave a linear relationship between P(n+1)/O(n+1) and Pn/On indicating the inner constraints between the olefin and the paraffin product distribution. Keywords Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Paraffin to olefin ratio Precipitated iron catalyst Product distribution Selectivity 1 Introduction Limitations in the supply of fossil fuel and associated CO2 emission are both driving forces for the development of renewable and sustainable energy system. Utilization of waste biomass via Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) has become a promising technique to meet the continuously increasing demand for liquid fuels and chemical feed stocks [1,2]. FTS converts syngas derived from waste biomass into olefins, paraffins and oxygenates with carbon numbers ranging from C1 to more than C100, in a manner that is analogous to polymerization mechanisms [3,4]. The raw syngas produced from biomass gasification is mainly a mixture of H2, CO, CO2 and N2. In some cases, the H2/CO ratio may be much lower than the stoichiometry ratio of the FT reaction (H2/CO = 2:1), and the CO2 composition can be as high as 35 % depending on the feed stocks, reaction conditions and type of gasifier [5–8]. Iron is one of the preferred metals for industrial FTS processes, not only because of its low cost, but also its high activity for both the FT and water-gas-shift (WGS) reactions which makes it tolerant to syngas with a low H2/CO ratio. Catalyst reduction is the first step in FTS; this entails catalyst activation using appropriate reducing agents (H2, CO or syngas) [9–14]. The active iron species formed after catalyst activation, and which are dispersed on the surface of the support, plays an important catalytic role in FTS [15]. If the catalyst could be reduced by the same syngas used for FT reaction and remain active when using a syngas with a relatively high CO2 content, the overall FT process could be simplified by eliminating the expensive H2 reduction and CO2 removal sections, which would make the economics of small-scale FT plant more attractive. It is therefore interesting to investigate the catalytic performance when using a syngas with low H2/CO ratio and a relatively high CO2 content as both activation agent and FTS feed. It has been reported that hydrogen pre-treatment produces metallic iron combined with unreduced hematite, while CO and syngas reduction produces iron carbides, combined with metallic iron and unreduced hematite [16–19]. The Hagg carbide (χ-Fe5C2) has been shown to have a higher FT activity compared to other carbide species [16,20–22]. Experimentally, the metallic iron formed after reduction with H2 has been shown to gradually transform into a mixture of carbide phases (such as: χ-Fe5C2 and ε-Fe2.2C) after the introduction of syngas [16–18]. The carbide phases formed on the catalyst surface during the FT reaction results in an increase in the FT activity for catalysts reduced with H2 [16]. Several studies done on the activation of Fe catalysts have reported that commonly used pre-treatment conditions can have significant effect on the catalyst activity, selectivity and lifetime [9–13,18,23,24]. Most of these studies relate to smaller TOS which is more appropriate for start up. In this study we will extend the TOS to times more appropriate to industrial situations. However, the influence of the reducing agent on the early TOS catalyst performance is complicated. Some literature suggests that syngas activation shows a more positive effect on FTS than H2 activation [18,24,25]. For instance, a very high catalyst activity of ca. 89.9 % was obtained for the catalyst 40 %Fe/Al2O3-Cr2O3 that was reduced by a syngas mixture, and it was quite stable during 96 h of FT operation [24]. However, some negative effects caused by the presence of CO in the reducing mixture have been also reported [16,23,26,27]. Bukur et al. [14] reported that a syngas activated catalyst was more active initially, while the H2 reduced catalyst showed a higher stability than that of the syngas reduced catalyst. In addition, a lower P/O ratio was obtained for the catalyst reduced by syngas, compared to the ones reduced by either CO or H2 [14]. Although the effect of pre-treatment atmosphere on the catalyst performance has been extensively studied, little information is available regarding its effect on the product selectivity during long-term FTS operation. The Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) distribution model has been used to describe the FTS product distribution using a constant chain growth probability (α) [28,29]. It is also widely accepted that olefin re-adsorption and the subsequent secondary reactions contribute to deviations from the ideal ASF model and lead to changes in the paraffin to olefin (P/O) ratio [9–13]. The P/O ratio is a crucial parameter that reflects the relative paraffin and olefin selectivity for FTS, which may be affected by several factors, such as type of reactor, catalyst, catalyst pre-treatment, reaction conditions (temperature, pressure, flowrate), and syngas composition (H2/CO/CO2/N2 ratio) etc. [3,9,10,12,13,15,30]. There has been much research on the product distribution over iron-based FTS, however, most of the studies were conducted for TOS’s less than 200 h. Unfortunately, there is little reported information on the variation of the P/O ratio for both short and long-term runs under different operating conditions for iron-based catalysts reduced with either syngas or H2. In addition, there is a little literature available on catalyst behaviour, especially P/O ratio, for catalysts activated using syngas. The “Yao Plot”, developed in previous publications by the author and collaborators [31–33], is a plot of P(n+1)/O(n+1) versus Pn/On; This graphical representation shows the relationship between the P/O ratio of adjacent carbon numbers. This unique approach reveals relationships that are not apparent from other graphical representations. Although the P/O ratio for FTS is strongly dependent on the operating conditions, the Yao Plot shows a linear relationship between P(n+1)/O(n+1) versus Pn/On for a large number of FT experiments [31–33], which can be described by the following equations. (1) P ( n + 1 ) O ( n + 1 ) = ε n P n O n By rearranging Eq. (1), we can obtain Eqs. (2) and (3): (2) P n + 1 P n = ε n O n + 1 O n (3) α P n = ε n α O n Where Pn is the formation rate of paraffin product of carbon number n; On is the formation rate of olefin product of carbon number n; α P n is the chain growth factor for paraffin with carbon number n; α O n is the chain growth factor for olefin with carbon number n; and ε n is a constant for carbon number n. In reality it has been found that ε n is independent of n when n>2 and this is the exciting new result. Thus Eq. (3) indicates that the olefin chain growth factor tracks the paraffin chain growth factor or vice versa. This plot seems to imply that if the olefin product distribution is known, then the paraffin product distribution could be predicted by using the above equations, which provide a method to simulate the olefin and paraffin product distribution for FTS. Another interpretation of Eq. (3), is that olefin and paraffin product distributions cannot be varied independently. As this graphical technique is quite new, more investigation is needed to test the range of applicability of the Yao plot. The major aim of this research is to extend the investigation of the effect of reducing agents, operating conditions and TOS on catalytic performance for both short-term and long-term FTS runs over a precipitated iron catalyst; focusing particularly on the product selectivity and P/O ratio. The data from this study will be represented on the Yao Plot to elucidate some of the observed behaviour and provide further understanding of the relationship between the paraffin and olefin product distribution particularly for industrial situations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The precipitated iron catalyst used in this study was prepared with the designated ratio of (100Fe/5Cu/4 K/25SiO2) by mass. The catalyst preparation method was adopted from the literature of [34]. All the chemicals used were supplied by Sigma-Aldrich. In brief, iron nitrate and copper nitrate were dissolved in distilled water with a composition of Fe/Cu = 100/5. The solution was heated to near boiling point and was then poured into a hot solution of sodium carbonate, which was stirred until the pH reached between 7–8. The precipitates were then filtered and washed with hot distilled water to remove the sodium. Thereafter, the washed precipitate was re-slurried with distilled water. The desired amount of potassium silicate was added to the slurry to give 25 g SiO2 per 100 g Fe. The excess potassium was removed by adding certain amount of nitric acid. Next, the slurry was dried at 120 °C for 16 h to produce a solid. The solid was then calcined for 6 h at 400 °C. After calcining, the precipitate was crushed to a particle size of 0.5−1 mm. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area and porosity of the precipitated iron catalyst were analysed by N2 physisorption using a Micromeritics Tristar II surface area and porosity analyzer. The elemental and phase analysis of the catalyst were performed using a MagiX PRO wavelength-dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) from Philips Analytical. The temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were carried out using a Micromeritics Auto Chem II unit. The cystal structure of the spent catalysts was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Bruker AXS D8 Advance with a Cu Ka source. 2.3 Catalyst reduction After drying at 120 °C with N2 for 1 h, a different reduction procedure was performed on the catalysts in the two different reactors: (1) For reactor 1 (R1), the same syngas used for FT reaction was used for reduction. The syngas composition was H2/CO/CO2/N2 = 35 %:35 %:20 %:10 %. The temperature was increased from 120 (drying temperature) to 230 °C (reduction temperature) at a heating rate of 1 °C/min. The system was then kept at 230 °C, 60 ml(NTP)/min and 1 bar gauge of syngas for 48 h prior to running the FT reaction. (2) Reactor 2 (R2), was reduced with pure H2 at 1 bar gauge, at a temperature of 300 °C and a flow rate of 60 mL(NTP)/(min gcat) for 48 h. 2.4 FT catalytic activity tests After reduction, the reaction conditions were kept the same as the reduction conditions for R1 (230 °C, 1 bar gauge) for 160 h time on stream (TOS). The pressure in the reactor was then gradually increased from 1 bar gauge to 6 bar gauge, while the flow rate and temperature were kept constant. Thereafter, reaction conditions were varied, (temperature changes from 230 °C up to 260 °C and flow rates dropped from 60 mL(NTP)/min to 8 m L(NTP)/min) until 6208 h TOS for R1. For R2, after reduction, the temperature was reduced to below 100 °C. The H2 reduction gas was then replaced with the same syngas used by R1 at 1 bar gauge, 60 mL (NTP)/min, and the temperature was increased to 230 °C. Thereafter, R2 followed the same reaction conditions as R1 until 5886 h TOS. During reaction, the tail gases were analysed using an online Dani GC. The liquid oil products were collected from the cold condensable product trap (maintained at room temperature). The wax products were collected in a condensable product trap (kept at 150 °C). The oil and wax products were analysed by an off-line GC, allowing for a complete mass balance calculation. In total, 13 different experimental conditions were tested, and we have labelled these Runs 1 to Runs 13 as shown in Table 1 . We grouped the runs into three groups, namely runs at 1 bar; “short” TOS runs and lastly longer TOS runs, again as indicated in Table 1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalyst The physical properties of the catalyst are listed in Table 2 . The chemical composition of the catalyst analysed by XRF was 100Fe/5.3Cu/3.8 K/28SiO2 by weight %. According to the N2 adsorption–desorption experiment, the BET surface area was 242.9 m2/g; the pore volume was 0.31 cm2/g; and the pore size was 4.87 nm. The reducibility of the catalyst was investigated using H2-TPR analysis and the result is shown in Fig. 1 . The catalyst shows a multi-step reduction profile; the first three peaks in Fig. 1 are partly overlapped, which corresponding to the transformation of CuO to Cu [35] and reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 and FeO [36,37], respectivtly. The fourth set of peaks ascribed to the further reduction of iron oxides to metallic iron (Fe3O4 (or FeO) to Fe). The identification of the reduction of CuO indicates that the copper oxide can be easily accessible by gas molecules for this precipitated catalyst [35,37]. Previous studies have proved that the addition of Cu promoter facilitates the reduction of iron oxides [35,37,38]. Fig. 1 indicates that, with the promotion of Cu, the catalyst can be reduced by H2 when the reduction temperature is higher than 200 °C. The precipitated iron catalyst reduced either in H2 or syngas was evaluated in FTS. After reaction (ca. 6000 h), the catalysts from both reactors were unloaded and then ground to small particles for XRD analysis, respectively. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the spent catalysts for R1 and R2, respectively. The peaks can be identified as a combination of iron carbides and iron oxides. Although the reduction conditions were different for the two reactors, the XRD patterns of the R1 and R2 catalysts after a long TOS (6000 h) were quite similar in terms of both phase constitution and the relative intensity. 3.2 Experimental results After reduction and reaction at 1 bar gauge, both reactors were pressurized to 6 bar gauge (see Table 1). A series of experiments (Run 2 – Run 11 in Table 1) were then conducted on both R1 and R2 and the reaction temperatures were varied from 230 °C to 250 °C and the flow rates decreased from 60 mL(NTP)/min to 15 m L(NTP)/min). Each of the reaction conditions was maintained for more than 48 h until the reactor output stabilized. The long term runs (corresponding to TOS from around 1000 h–6000 h) were used to investigate how the reducing agents affected the long term catalytic performance (more appropriate for industrial operating conditions), including the activity, selectivity and stability (Run 12 and Run 13 in Table 1). 3.2.1 Catalyst activity and product selectivity 3.2.1.1 Experimental runs for short TOS The CO conversions and product selectivities as a function of flowrate and temperature are plotted in Figs. 3 and 4 , respectively. The CO conversion and CO2 selectivity decreased with increasing flow rate, while the CH4 and C5+ selectivities increased slightly in both R1 and R2 at 6 bar and 250 °C (Fig. 3). When the temperature in R1 was increased (with pressure kept constant at 6 bar and the flowrate held at 15 mi(NTP)/min), the CO conversion, CH4 and CO2 selectivity all increased with increased reaction temperature. It was observed the that CO conversion in R2 also increased with increasing reactor temperature; however, the selectivities of CH4, CO2 and C5+ in R2 did not change much with reaction temperature. It is worth noting that the catalyst reduced by syngas had a better catalytic performance, in terms of higher activity and slightly lower methane selectivity for the short TOS’s for the reaction conditions used in Runs 2 to 11 as shown in Table 1. As already stated, the catalyst activity and selectivity are influenced significantly by the atmosphere used in the reductive pre-treatment, for example H2 or syngas. For iron based catalysts, H2 reduction produces metallic iron, while syngas reduction produces both iron carbides and metallic iron [16–19]. Carbides are more active than metallic iron for FTS [16,24,25]. Compared with the experimental results reported in the literature [16,24,25], the higher activity measured in this work when the catalyst was pre-treated with syngas may be due to the formation of iron carbides during catalyst reduction. These experimental results indicated that the iron catalyst could be reduced by the syngas of (35 %CO/35 % H2/ 20 %CO2/10 %N2) at a normal FT reaction temperature (230 °C). The CO2 selectivity changed from 28 % to 36 % during the different reaction conditions tested, as is shown in Figs. 3(d) and 4 (d), which indicates that the iron catalyst used in this study had both FT (CO + 2H2 = [−CH2-] + H2O) and WGS (CO + H2O = CO2 + H2) activity. In summary, this catalyst could be reduced by a CO2 containing syngas and could be used for FTS using a syngas feed with a low H2/CO ratio. 3.2.2 Experimental runs for long TOS The CO conversion as a function of TOS is shown in Fig. 5 (a). The initial CO conversion for R1 was much higher than that of R2 (65 % conversion in R1 compared to 43 % in R2). The activity in R1 decreased gradually with TOS during Run 12. The CO conversion in R2 initially dropped slightly, and then increased to the same level as that found in R1, and thereafter decreased gradually and followed a similar trend to R1. When the conversion for both reactors was below 40 %, the reaction temperature was increased to 260 °C (Run 13), while the pressure and the flowrate were kept the same. The data in Fig. 5(a) clearly shows that the CO conversion initially increased from 37.6%–49.9% in R1 and from 29.3%–39.5% in R2, and then gradually decreased in both reactors with increasing TOS. The CH4 selectivity as a function of TOS is shown in Fig. 5(b). The CH4 selectivity in R1 was slightly lower than in R2. The selectivity was less than 7% for all the runs conducted. The CH4 selectivity increased firstly with increasing TOS and then maintained a similar and constant value for both R1 and R2. The C5+ selectivity (Fig. 5(c)) and CO2 selectivity (Fig. 5(d)) were very similar and did not change much with TOS for both reactors. Fig. 5 indicates that both reactors performed similarly for TOS’s greater than 2000 h. The similar catalyst performance for both reactors may be due to the similar active phases and crystal structures in the catalysts as shown in the XRD patterns in Fig. 2. The use of syngas as both an activation agent and FT reaction gas could potentially drop both capital and operating costs, especially for small biomass to liquid fuel processes, by eliminating the use of expensive H2 and H2 reduction facilities. 3.2.3 Paraffin to Olefin ratio (P/O) P/O describes the relative amount of paraffin to olefin in the feed and is a key factor in determining product quality and value. A higher P/O ratio corresponds to a higher alkane selectivity, while a lower value indicates that the catalyst produces more alkenes. 3.2.3.1 Run 1: results and comparison of R1 and R2 R1 was activated by syngas at 230 °C and 1 bar gauge. Two hours after syngas was introduced into the reactor, the GC indicated peaks corresponding to hydrocarbons in the product, including both paraffins and olefins, which indicates that the syngas used for the FT reaction can reduce the iron catalyst at normal FT reaction temperatures. Low CO conversions were obtained, between 2%–4%, during this “reduction”. The paraffin to olefin ratio (P/O) for carbon numbers 2–5 (P2/O2, P3/O3, P4/O4 and P5/O5) are plotted in Fig. 6 (a) for R1. The ratios show an initial decrease and then increase to achieve steady state for the light products. Fig. 6(a) clearly shows that the values of the P/O ratios at steady state are more than two times higher than the initial ones, which indicates the more the catalyst is reduced, the higher the selectivity to paraffin products. In addition, the P/O ratio changes as a function of carbon number; increasing as the carbon number increases the P/O ratio with the exception of P2/O2, which is in line with the reported results [31,39,40]. The trends observed in P/O ratio with TOS in R2 were similar to those in R1 (see Fig. 6(b)), namely: the P/O ratios at TOS =160 h are much higher than those at TOS = 20 h; the P/O ratio increases with increasing carbon number (excluding P2/O2). 3.2.3.2 Short TOS: run 2 to run 11 Table 3 lists the P/O ratios measured for Runs 2–11 for both reactors R1 and R2. The effect of the reaction conditions on the P/O ratios was different for R1 and R2. P/O ratios for R2 are more sensitive to the temperature and flowrate than those for R2. The P/O ratios increased with increasing temperature and decreasing flow rate for R1. Although similar trends for P2/O2 were observed for both reactors, the P/O ratios (n = 3, 4 and 5) did not change much for R2 under the reaction conditions tested. Run 3 and Run 8 were operated at the same reaction conditions, but at different TOS’s (Table 1). The CO conversion dropped from 12.1%–11.4% for R1 and from 8.9 to 8.2 for R2 for these two runs. Although both R1 and R2 showed a slightly lower CO conversions for Run 8, the changing trends for the P/O ratios were different: the P/O ratios for R1 were similar for both runs; however, lower P/O ratios were obtained for Run 8 (excluding P6/O6) for R2. A comparison of the results from Run 3 and Run 8 indicates that although the same operating conditions were used, the catalyst activity and the P/O ratio were a function of TOS. Therefore, it is worth investigating the catalytic stability and product selectivity for longer TOS’s. 3.2.3.3 Long TOS: run 12 and run 13 Fig. 7 (b–e) shows the P/O ratios for carbon numbers 2–6. It is observed that: (1) Initially, R1 had a much higher P/O ratio than R2. (2) With TOS’s from 1100 h to 2200 h, the changes in the P/O ratios follow similar trends to the variation in CO conversion in both R1 and R2, respectively. For example: R1 shows that the P/O dropped when CO conversion decreased; R2 shows the P/O drops slightly and then increases in the same way as the CO conversion. (3) for TOS from 2200 h to 4865 h, although the CO conversion decreased for both R1 and R2, the P/O ratios stayed at similar levels and did not change much. (4) for TOS’s from 4866 h to the end of Run 13, the P/O ratios initially increased and then decreased until they returned to similar P/O ratio as found at 250 °C; thereafter, although the CO conversions for both reactors decreased further, the P/O ratios did not change much. It is worth noting that the data in Fig. 7 indicates that the activity and selectivity for both reactors were similar and independent of the catalyst activation method after 2200 h TOS. Ding et al. [16] reported that the formation of iron carbides (especially for χ-Fe2.5C) on the surface layers could provide active sites for FTS, whereas the Fe3O4 formed plays a negligible role in FTS activity. During FTS, the amount of iron carbides on the surface of the catalyst could increase which would lead to an increase in the CO conversion for TOS from 1200 h to 2200 h for R2, with the P/O increasing indicating that more paraffin was formed. 3.2.4 The relationship between P(n+1) /O(n+1) and Pn/On The observed trends in the P/O ratios are difficult to either predict or summarise, because they are strongly dependant on the operating conditions, such as reducing agent, pressure, temperature, flow rate and TOS (see the results from Figs. 6 and 7 and Table 3). To address these challenges, a new approach, called the Yao Plot, has been used to plot the data. Applying the Yao Plot to the current data may help identify trends in the P/O ratios. Fig. 8 shows the plot of P(n+1)/O(n+1) versus Pn/On for carbon numbers n = 2−5. It can be clearly seen that there is a nearly linear relationship between P(n+1)/O(n+1) and Pn/On for both R1 and R2 for n = 2−5. The P/O data for both R1 and R2 were combined and the results are presented in Fig. 9. Although the variation of the P/O ratios were different, the relationships between P(n+1)/O(n+1) and Pn/On were the same for R1 and R2 for all experimental conditions; the slopes were less than 1 for n = 2 and higher than 1 for n>2. These values are in line with the values obtained in our previous study [31]. In particular, the data used in Figs. 8 and 9 cover data during reduction with syngas, short-term runs with different temperatures and flowrates and long-term runs with a TOS of around 6000 h, including unsteady state and steady state operation for R1 and R2. It is interesting to note that the plot of P3/O3 against P2/O2 shows a linear relationship, but the trend line does not pass through the origin [0, 0], (see the trend line in Fig. 9(a)). Similar trends were also observed in our previous publication [31], where the Yao plot was applied to the published data from other researchers. The intercept of the trend line indicates that when P2/O2 = 0, the ratio of P3/O3 is around 0.1. For comparison, the trend line in Fig. 9(b) was forced to pass through the origin. It is observed that at higher P/O ratios, this is not a bad approximation, but for more olefinic products, this is not a good approximation, which is clearly shown in Fig. 10 (b) for n = 2. More research needs to be done to further explore this phenomenon. The data presented in Fig. 9 was combined, and plotted in Fig. 10(a), which shows the average slope for the data with n = 3, 4, and 5 is around 1.3. The comparison between the current data and the data reported in previous research is shown in Fig. 10(b). This indicates that the current results are in line with other published data, which covers different catalysts, operating conditions and reactor types [31]; although there may be slight differences in the gradients. This study shows that the trends in the Yao Plot are followed at both steady state and unsteady conditions as well as all TOS, including TOS’s of up to 6000 h. A comparison of the data from Run 12 for R1 and R2 (corresponding to around 3700 h of operation at 6 bar, 8 m L(NTP)/min, 250 °C) gives some interesting insights. Fig. 11 shows the change in P/O ratio with TOS for both reactors for n = 4,5. The arrows in Fig. 11 show the direction of increasing TOS, and it can be seen that over a long time, the P/O ratios for R1 and R2 tend to the same values. These results clearly indicate that no matter which kind of reducing agent is used, the P/O ratios tend to the same values for a precipitated iron catalyst. However, it took almost 2200 h of operation to see this phenomenon (Fig. 7), which indicate that the active species on the catalyst surface are slowly adjusting and that it takes a fairly long time to get a steady state surface composition for this precipitated iron catalyst. 4 Discussion and application of the Yao plot The Yao plot is described by Eqs. (1–3). According to the experimental evidence, the constant ε n for n greater than 2 has an average value of 1.3 (Fig. 10) and is independent of the operating conditions, type of reactor and catalyst. In this study, the liner relationship for P3/O3 against P2/O2 does not pass through the origin [0,0], the ε 2 has an average value of 0.1 with an intercept around 0.1 (Fig. 10(a)). If we substitute the value of these constants into Eq. (1–3), we find the following: For n = 2: (4) P 3 O 3 = 0.1 P 2 O 2 + 0.1 or (5) α P 2 = 0.1 α O 2 + 0.1 O 3 P 2 For n>2: (6) P ( n + 1 ) O ( n + 1 ) = 1.3 P n O n which gives (7) P n + 1 P n = 1.3 O n + 1 O n or (8) α P n = 1.3 α O n If we assume: • both paraffins and olefins for n > 2 follow a typical ASF product distribution, respectively; • the value of olefin chain growth FT reaction rate (RFT), the formation rates of methane (P1), ethane (P2), ethene (O2) and propylene (O3) are given Then, by using the Eqs. (4–8), we could plot the olefin, paraffin and total product distribution. Fig. 12 shows the comparison between the experimental data and the data simulated by using Eqs (4–8). The model fits the experimental data fairly well. The experimental data indicates that the light olefin and paraffin products follow an ASF distribution for n>2. In addition, the chain growth factor for paraffins (0.90) is higher than that for olefins (0.74). By combining the calculated formation rates of olefin and paraffin products, the total product distribution was also plotted in Fig. 12 (the green line). The predicted data clearly show a two-α ASF product distribution, which indicates the different chain growth factors between olefin and paraffin products may contribute to the two-alpha ASF product distribution. The alpha values are in an order of: α O n < α 1 < α 2 < α P n . Because ε n is higher than 1 for n>2, the chain growth factor of the paraffin products will always be higher than the chain growth factor of the olefin products; this has been observed by many researchers [39,41–43]. Our research previously tried to explain the phenomenon showed from the graph of the“Yao Plot” using vapor liquid equilibrium (VLE), for more details please refer to [31]. The solubility of the hydrocarbons in the wax phase covering the catalyst surface may influence the re-adsorption and desorption of the olefin products, which affects the possibility of the secondary reaction of olefins and thus the overall product distribution of FTS [31]. However, when the catalyst was activated with syngas in R1 at 230 °C at 1 bar gauge (R1_Run 1 in Table 1), although the light hydrocarbon products were detected during the catalyst reduction, the CO conversion was less than 4% (Table 1), and it would be unlikely that a liquid layer accumulated on the catalyst surface at such a low pressure and low activity, implying that the variation in solubilities of the hydrocarbons in wax phase is not the reason for the behaviour observed. More work needs to be done to explain the linear relationship between P(n+1)/O(n+1) and Pn/On that is observed for all these different experiments, including low pressure and low conversion where the formation of a liquid layer on or in the catalyst is highly unlikely (Figs. 8–10). 5 Conclusions The effect of the activating agent (H2 and syngas), operating conditions and TOS on the catalyst performance over a precipitated iron catalyst for both short-term and long-term operation was investigated. Experimental data shows that activation with syngas led to better initial catalyst activity, which indicates that the iron catalyst used can be activated by syngas at the normal FT reaction temperatures. During the catalyst activation with syngas at 1 bar, the P/O ratios increased with TOS and reached a steady state. For the short-term FT runs for both R1 and R2, CO conversion increased with increasing temperature and decreasing flowrate. The product selectivity including methane and C5+ selectivity does not change much with changing the temperature and flowrate. The P/O ratios also increased with increasing temperature and decreasing flow rate for R1, while the P/O ratios did not change much for the catalyst reduced by H2 (R2). For the long-term FT runs, corresponding to TOS from 1100 to 2200 h: (1) the reaction conversion and P/O ratio were higher for the catalyst reduced with syngas (R1); (2) the P/O ratios dropped when CO conversion decreased from 65 % to 46 % for the catalyst reduced with syngas (R1); (3) the change in the P/O ratio follows a similar trend to the CO conversion for the catalyst reduced with H2 (R2); it firstly dropped a little bit, and then increased to almost the same level as R1. For the experiments during TOS from 2200 to 4800 h, the CO conversions were very similar in R1 and R2 and gradually decreased with TOS. However, the product selectivity and the P/O ratio remained fairly constant for both R1 and R2. A new method, called the “Yao Plot”, was used to analyse the data. Although the P/O ratio strongly depends on the operating conditions, a plot of P(n+1)/O(n+1) versus Pn/On (“Yao Plot”) shows the same linear relationship for all TOS, including unsteady state and steady state results for all the data from both R1 and R2. This indicates a dependant relationship between the olefin and paraffin alphas. This result was previously found and reported and it was shown that the data from other researchers who used different catalysts, operating conditions and reactor types also fitted the plot [31]. This implies that it may not be possible, either through catalyst or reactor design and operation, to independently vary the olefin and paraffin product distributions. coredata.dc:description: The effect of activating atmosphere, reaction conditions and time on stream (TOS) on the catalytic performance and especially on the paraffin to olefin ratios (P/O) over an iron catalyst during Fischer-Tropsch synthesis was investigated. Activation with syngas led to better catalyst performance. For the long-term FT runs, although a higher catalytic activity and P/O ratio have been measured for the catalyst reduced by syngas, similar CO conversions, P/O ratios and product selectivity were achieved for the catalysts reduced by either syngas or H2 after 2200 h TOS, which indicates that no matter which kind of reducing agent is used to reduce the catalyst, the catalyst performance tends to be similar after a long TOS. Despite the P/O variations with different reaction conditions, a graphical approach (Yao plot) gave a linear relationship between P(n+1)/O(n+1) and Pn/On indicating the inner constraints between the olefin and the paraffin product distribution.
coredata.dc:title: Fischer-Tropsch synthesis: A long term comparative study of the product selectivity and paraffin to olefin ratios over an iron-based catalyst activated by syngas or H2
